ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This course is very effective at teaching writing, reading and speaking skills of Yoruba. I feel confident carrying out Yoruba conversations and reading Yoruba passages at a basic level after this semester.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Great professor but a lot of homework

There are many strengths of this course. One of the first that comes to mind is the upbeat and productive class environment. Also, Seye and Doyin are very helpful with answering questions. They do a great job of teaching us material. If anything, I think one of the few weaknesses would be that sometimes the material moves a little fast, with some students falling behind.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, a great language to take and very interesting. However, this is a hard language to grasp but Prof. Adesola does a good job of helping struggling students and makes an effort to get to know everybody.

This is a great class that is challenging but not impossible in the way some language classes are at Yale. Professor Oluseye is a kind man who takes his work seriously but also has a great sense of humor that I appreciated every morning. While participation is required, it is well paced and the classroom environment is wonderful; I was not scared to ask questions or answer the ones I knew.
